ZT2Strings.LOC_STRING: Vulnerable Animals Adoption Program

Captive breeding is a strong indication of a zoo's ongoing commitment to wildlife conservation. The major donors backing your zoo are so committed to conservation that they have put a restriction on your ability to adopt animals from other facilities. They are insisting that you develop a thriving breeding and active adoption program so that you can offer animals to other facilities.
Meet the advanced needs of your animals to encourage reproduction. Don't let your animals become too crowded in their exhibits. Put extra animals up for adoption to other facilities but make sure you keep enough of an animal stock so that you can continue to maintain a growing and thriving animal community.
You will receive an adoption fee for each animal adopted by another facility and all funds raised through the adoption program will allow you to better provide for special diets, animal enrichment toys and comfortable homes for your animals.

Captive breeding is a strong indication of a zoo's ongoing commitment to wildlife conservation. Develop a thriving breeding and active adoption program so that you can offer animals to other facilities.

Your breeding program has successfully added to the world's vulnerable animal population. You have had enough animal births to support placing your animals up for adoption to other facilitiesand in doing so you have contributed to the conservation of these important animals.

You have neglected to keep enough mixed gender animals to maintain a breeding program. Unfortunately you have no way to breed your animals to support any sort of adoption drive. Contrary to the wishes of your zoo's major donors, you would have no choice now but to adopt additional animals.
Animal Adoption program a success!
Breed your animals and offer extra animals up for adoption. You must put at least 6 animals up for adoption but make sure that you have at least as many animals as when you started.
You have successfully placed one animal up for adoption!
You have successfully placed two animals up for adoption!
You have successfully placed three animals up for adoption!
You have successfully placed four animals up for adoption!
You have successfully placed five animals up for adoption!

Your exceptional breeding program has allowed you to place six animals up for adoption! Your donors are satisfied that you've made a positive impact on conservation by supplying other facilities through this adoption program.
Oh no! You no longer have enough of an animal stock to continue your breeding program. Your donors are very disappointed.
Endangered Animals Species Survival

The birth of any baby animal is always a momentous occasion but the captive breeding of endangered animals is an important, proactive way of ensuring species survival.
Guests particularly enjoy seeing baby animals. When the species is endangered, it makes even more of an impact and guests are more likely to make generous donations when they view these special babies.
Meet the advanced needs of your Mountain Gorillas, Red Pandas and Snow Leopards to encourage their reproduction. Achieve $2000 in donations for each of these endangered animals.

The birth of any baby animal is always a momentous occasion but the captive breeding of endangered animals is an important, proactive way of ensuring species survival. Do your part to encourage the reproduction of several species of endangered animals.

Your breeding program has made a superb contribution to the survival of several endangered species. Guests really enjoy viewing baby animals and when those babies are endangered, it's even more appealing. The extra appeal of these babies is likely to increase your donation revenue.

You have had excellent results obtaining additional revenue from donations. This additional income will allow your zoo even more flexibility to fund new exhibits, improve animal accomodations or expand the amenities available to your guests.
Endangered animals thriving!
Breed your Mountain Gorillas.
Breed your Red Pandas.
Breed your Snow Leopards.
Great! You've successfully bred Mountain Gorillas!
Great! You've successfully bred Red Pandas!
Great! You've successfully bred Snow Leopards!
Oh no! You no longer have enough of an animal stock to continue your breeding program.
You have neglected to keep enough mixed gender animals to maintain a breeding program. Unfortunately you have no way to breed your animals to support a conservation program for endangered animals.
Now that you have a Mountain Gorilla baby, achieve $2000 in donations for your Mountain Gorillas.
Now that you have a Red Panda baby, achieve $2000 in donations for your Red Pandas.
Now that you have a Snow Leopard baby ,achieve $2000 in donations for your Snow Leopards.
You have received at least $2000 in donations for your Mountain Gorillas.
You have received at least $2000 in donations for your Red Pandas.
You have received at least $2000 in donations for your Snow Leopards.
Second Generation Animals

Breeding animals in captivity is a difficult venture that many zoos strive to add to their list of accomplishments. Successfully breeding second-generation animals is even more challenging. Establish a thriving breeding program where any of your animals breed second generation animals, and your zoo will be added to the list of the select few who have successfully supported multiple breeding generations.

Breeding animals in captivity is a difficult venture that many zoos strive to add to their list of accomplishments. Successfully breeding second-generation animals is even more challenging. Can your zoo be one of the few than can boast of this accomplishment?

Few facilities can boast that they have successfully bred second generation animals. You have been added to a list of the select few who can make this claim. Your notoriety in the world of zoos is certain to be widespread and the births of your animal additions have made headlines around the world.
You have neglected to keep enough mixed gender animals to maintain a breeding program and achieving the select status of breeding multiple generations of animals is out of your grasp.
A thriving animal community!
Successfully breed any of your animals such that the offspring of animals bred in your zoo are also successfully bred.
Your Common Zebras have produced their first offspring!
The offspring of your Common Zebras have produced a second generation of Zebras!
Your Lemurs have produced their first offspring!
The offspring of your Lemurs have produced a second generation of Lemurs!
Your Chimpanzees have produced their first offspring!
The offspring of your Chimpanzees have produced a second generation of Chimpanzees!
Congratulations! Very few facilities can say they have successfully bred second generation animals. You have been added to a list of the select few that have.
Oh no! You no longer have enough of an animal stock to continue your breeding program.
